name: Axiom Prime-Coordinate Homomorphism Formalization
description: The mathematical formalization of the Prime-Coordinate Homomorphism Axiom, defining the mapping from objects to their prime exponent vectors with precise notation.
text:
The Prime-Coordinate Homomorphism can be formalized with precise mathematical notation to capture its essential properties.

Given a universe of objects ùí∞ with composition operation ‚àò, and a set of primes P, the prime coordinate map œÜ is a function:

œÜ: ùí∞ ‚Üí ‚Ñ§^(P)

where ‚Ñ§^(P) denotes the space of integer vectors indexed by the set of primes P. For each object X in ùí∞ and each prime p in P, the prime coordinate map is defined as:

œÜ(X)(p) = the exponent of prime p in X's factorization

In other words, if the prime factorization of X is X = p‚ÇÅ^(e‚ÇÅ) ‚àò p‚ÇÇ^(e‚ÇÇ) ‚àò ... ‚àò p‚Çô^(e‚Çô), then œÜ(X) is the vector (e‚ÇÅ, e‚ÇÇ, ..., e‚Çô) where each component corresponds to the exponent of a specific prime.

The homomorphism property states that for any two objects X and Y in ùí∞:

œÜ(X‚àòY) = œÜ(X) + œÜ(Y)

This critical property transforms the multiplicative structure of object composition into the additive structure of vector addition. It means that combining objects through composition corresponds precisely to adding their coordinate vectors component-wise.

The injectivity property ensures that for any two distinct objects X and Y in ùí∞:

If X ‚â† Y, then œÜ(X) ‚â† œÜ(Y)

This guarantees that each object has a unique prime coordinate representation, with no two different objects mapping to the same coordinates.

For computational purposes, we can also define œÜ‚Åª¬π, the inverse mapping from coordinates back to objects:

œÜ‚Åª¬π((e‚ÇÅ, e‚ÇÇ, ..., e‚Çô)) = p‚ÇÅ^(e‚ÇÅ) ‚àò p‚ÇÇ^(e‚ÇÇ) ‚àò ... ‚àò p‚Çô^(e‚Çô)

This formalization provides a rigorous mathematical foundation for the coordinate representation system, enabling precise analysis and application across diverse domains.
